title: Did you know Killing Eve is different from the original Villanelle books? Here's how...
text:
From Good Housekeeping

When Killing Eve made its debut on the BBC in 2018, it quickly became the most talked about shows in offices and pubs alike. A cat-and-mouse thriller centred around heartless assassin Villanelle and MI5 agent Eve Polastri, both the first and second season, which came out in May this year, had us all hooked.

But before it was a buzzy BBC drama starring Doctor Foster’s Jodie Comer and Grey’s Anatomy’s Sandra Oh, Killing Eve was actually a book by author Luke Jennings. Here’s everything you need to know about the novels that inspired the Killing Eve series.

What are the Villanelle novels?

The original Killing Eve books were written by Luke Jennings as a series of four self-published e-book novellas called Codename Villanelle, Villanelle: Hallowpoint, Villanelle: Shanghai and Odessa. They were published between 2014 and 2016, and were later compiled into one book which came out in 2018.

In March 2019, Jennings followed up with a sequel Killing Eve: No Tomorrow, and the third and final book in the series Killing Eve: Endgame is due to be published in March 2020.

Who adapted the Villanelle novels into Killing Eve for TV?

While the Villanelle novellas didn’t become bestsellers at the time, television producer Sally Woodward Gentle spotted the potential for a TV show. She approached Fleabag’s Phoebe Waller-Bridge to bring her on board as the writer. It was later commissioned by BBC America.

“Sally actually put the novellas in front of me, which is how the conversation started," Waller-Bridge said at a Television Critics Association Press Tour in January 2018. "I read the first novella and just fell in love with these characters, thought they were just wild. I hadn’t seen them before and just was desperate to stand them up.”

Waller-Bridge adapted the first season for TV, then handed the baton on to Emerald Fennell. In April, it was announced season three of Killing Eve will be written and adapted by Suzanne Heathcote.

How different are the Villanelle to the Killing Eve show?

The creative team behind Killing Eve’s TV show have described Jennings’ novellas as an inspiration and start-off point, rather than something they follow closely.

That means there are quite a few differences between the show and the books. Here’s how the Villanelle books are different:

Villanelle has much more of a backstory

We learn some major things about the Villanelle in Jennings’ books. We know her as Oxana from the first few pages and that her father was a wealthy war veteran who turned to crime later in life.

After her mother died from cancer when Oxana was young, she became very close with her father, but he was killed by rival criminals. Vowing revenge, Oxana murders her father's killers – and that’s what ends her in prison.

Her merciless murders caught the attention of The Twelve, though, who rescue her from prison and give her a whole new persona. She’s known as Villanelle from then on.

Photo credit: BBC America More

Eve Polastri isn’t American

While MI5 agent Eve Polastri is from the US in the show, in Jennings’ novellas she’s British.

As well as this, Sandra Oh who plays Eve said at the Television Critics Association panel: “Eve was, as I interpreted the novella, white. I am not white. I am Asian. And I will say that I was extremely pleased that that was taken into consideration in the casting.”
description: We deep-dive into the books that inspired the hit BBC series
